The code below will include IM and give all paragraph elements a mouseenter/mouseleave effect.

IMPORTANT: for larger apps you will often find yourself doing a lot of CSS selectors 'onready' initializing your widgets and other UI elements. In such cases there is an optimized way to trigger this initializing code using im.scan. Also, it is advised to take time to properly design your page initialisation setup.

The HTML:

<!DOCTYPE "html"> <html> <head> <script src="im.min.js"></script> <script src="myApp.js"></script> </head> <body> <div> <p> Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet. </p> <p> Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet. </p> </div> </body> </html>

myApp.js

/* we typically execute our code onready (when the DOM is ready), rather than onload. */ im.onready(function(){ im('p').bind('mouseenter', function(){ im(this).css({backgroundColor : 'red'}); }).bind('mouseleave', function(){ im(this).css({backgroundColor : 'blue'}); }); }); /* code above can also be writting with the shorthand for im.onready: im(function(){ // code }); */
